title: Trump Administration Eases U.S. Restrictions on Use of Land Mines
summary: New policy marks return to weapons that other countries view as illegal, humanitarian groups say. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration said it is reversing an Obama-era ban on certain kinds of land mines, adopting a new policy in an effort to expand military weaponry.

title: Chicago's Puerto Rican Bonds
summary: Junk debt secured with sales-tax revenue. Sounds familiar.. Nobody knows what market distortions the Federal Reserve's prolonged ultra-low interest rates are creating, but count progressive local governments as big winners. Behold how Puerto Rico on Lake Michigan, otherwise known as Chicago, is financing budget deficits and public pensions with cheap debt.

title: McDonald's, Nike, Amazon.com: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on this week's news. McDonald's Corp.

title: Pompeo Assures Ukraine of U.S. Support Against Russia
summary: The U.S. secretary of state's visit came as Kyiv is drawn into President Trump's impeachment trial in Washington. MOSCOW-Secretary of State Mike Pompeo assured Ukraine of the U.S.'s full support in its territorial disputes with Russia as the impeachment trial of President Trump, sparked by his pressing Ukraine to investigate a political rival, continued to unfold in Washington.

title: Cerberus in Union's Crosshairs as Firm Prepares Albertsons IPO
summary: The grocery chain operator, which Cerberus is reportedly preparing to take public, is battling workers over a critically underfunded pension plan. As Cerberus Capital Management prepares to take Albertsons Cos. public, some of the grocery company's workers are waging a campaign against the private-equity firm, saying it is squeezing them for its own financial gain.

title: Caterpillar Drives Down Expectations for 2020
summary: Profit rises on cost controls, but machinery giant and others see more weak demand ahead. Caterpillar Inc. said it expects demand for its machinery to fall this year, widening a performance gap between some manufacturers and an otherwise robust U.S. economy.

title: Democrats May Be Blowing Their Chance
summary: Progressives seem to be forgetting the opponent is Donald Trump, not Bill Clinton or Barack Obama.. Reform is often more effective than revolution. Amid the heated rhetoric now blowing through Iowa, Democrats appear to be losing sight of that. Progressivism isn't a destination-it's an orientation. Purists are anxious to box some of us out by narrowing the definition, but we all share in the mission of using government's tools to serve those who have been left behind. The next nine months will present our raucous coalition a rare opportunity to establish a new Democratic "metropolitan majority" that could last for years. We can't afford to let internecine disagreements about how to reach our common goals get in the way.

title: Seattle and the State Supreme Court Wage War on Property Rights
summary: Landlords are forced to rent to the first person who walks in-even if he has a criminal record.. Affordable-housing shortages are an abiding challenge for cities around the nation. But often policies meant to alleviate the problem aggravate it instead. That's certainly the case in Seattle, where the City Council imposed a pair of ordinances aimed at restricting property owners' right to choose their tenants.

title: Thanks to Congress, America Is Prepared for the Coronavirus
summary: Lawmakers created a reserve fund, now $100 million, for public-health emergencies like this one.. The world watches with concern as the virus originating in Wuhan affects more nations. While it's still too soon to know if this coronavirus strain will become a pandemic, Americans should take some comfort: Thanks to the bipartisan foresight of Congress and lessons learned in the past five years, the U.S. is in better shape today than at any other time in recent memory to confront a major public-health crisis.

title: Notable & Quotable: Max Singer on Truth and Mideast Peace
summary: 'Parroting Palestinian falsehoods harms the cause of peace.'. From "Refute Palestinian Lies to Promote Mideast Peace" by Max Singer, a founder of the Hudson Institute, The Wall Street Journal, Dec. 7, 2018. Singer died Jan. 23 at 88:

title: Treasury Bond Yields Fall to Three-Month Low
summary: Potential global slowdown stokes rate-cut expectations. Treasury bond yields hit lows on Friday not breached since October as concern mounts that the spread of the coronavirus and accompanying production shutdowns could significantly slow global economic growth through the first half of 2020.

title: Ray Dalio Is Still Driving His $160 Billion Hedge-Fund Machine
summary: The billionaire had a plan to give up stewardship of Bridgewater, the world's largest hedge-fund firm. A decade later, his word nearly always wins out.. Ray Dalio had a 10-year succession plan for Bridgewater Associates LP, the hedge fund he built. It's year 10. He's still in charge.

title: FDA Approves First Drug for Peanut Allergy
summary: Maker of new treatment, named Palforzia, is Aimmune Therapeutics. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first treatment for peanut allergy, providing a new option for the growing number of children and their families dealing with the life-threatening condition.

title: Hulu CEO to Exit as Part of Disney Restructuring
summary: Disney is integrating Hulu with its direct-to-consumer business segment. Randy Freer is exiting as chief executive of Hulu as Walt Disney Co. integrates the streaming service more closely into its direct-to-consumer business operations, the company said Friday.

title: A Good Sport Is Hard to Find, Especially in the NFL
summary: Athletes have traded decency and decorum for triumphal dances and muscle flexing struts.. I recall, during my high-school days in the early Pleistocene, a basketball game on our home-court at Senn High School in Chicago. The kids from my school, for reasons I no longer recall, began booing the visiting team. After a minute or two, Senn's coach, a man named Cap Leighton-imagine John Wayne but with white hair and a much lower income-strode to the scorer's table, grasped the microphone, and instructed us that booing the other team was unsportsmanlike and therefore unacceptable, and it needed to stop now. Such was Coach Leighton's authority that it did stop, straightaway. For the remainder of the game we restricted ourselves to cheering on our own team.

title: Brexit Is Done: The U.K. Has Left the European Union
summary: As midnight tolled in Brussels, Britain embarked on a new course in the world. LONDON-The U.K. formally quit the European Union late Friday, closing the chapter on nearly half a century of integration with its European neighbors as it begins to chart a new and uncertain course in the world.

title: U.S. Targets Yemen Al Qaeda Leader in Drone Strike
summary: Officials say it is not clear if this week's strike, aimed at Qasim al-Raymi, was successful. WASHINGTON-The U.S. launched a recent drone strike against the leader of al Qaeda's Yemen branch, although it wasn't clear on Friday whether he was killed as a result, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Forever 21 in Talks on Sale to Mall Owners and Authentic Brands
summary: Landlords Simon Property and Brookfield are teaming with licensing firm to bid on bankrupt fast-fashion retailer. Simon Property Group Inc., Brookfield Property Partners LP and Authentic Brands Group LLC are teaming up to make a bid for Forever 21 Inc. at an auction Tuesday, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Forget the Bathroom Break! Play Our Super Bowl Ad Bingo.
summary: Your favorite team may not be in the Super Bowl, but you can still enjoy the action! Watch the Big Game for the memorable commercials, then cover the squares.. The ad battle on Super Bowl Sunday has become its own sporting event.

title: Amazon Joins, Then Leaves, the $1 Trillion Club
summary: Shares jumped on strong earnings report but fell 8 cents short of closing at milestone valuation. Amazon.com Inc. shares jumped 7.4% Friday, reflecting the company's transformation from an upstart famously uninterested in profits into a giant that generates abundant cash, but fell 8 cents short of ending the day with a trillion-dollar market valuation.

title: Dow Drops 600 Points on Global Growth Concerns
summary: Anxiety swept through multiple markets on Friday with uncertainty over economic impact of coronavirus. U.S. stocks capped off a turbulent week with a punishing selloff as the spreading coronavirus outbreak fanned fears about global economic growth.

title: 'Islamic Empires' Review: Revisiting a Glorious Past
summary: Debate thrived, music was composed, architecture was built by rulers who sought to outdo one another in splendor. Justin Marozzi is a British journalist and popular historian who frequented such places as Egypt and Libya as a boy. His father was born in Beirut in 1938 to an Italian father and a Prussian mother who had fled to Lebanon from impending war in Europe. His great-grandmother, he discovered only recently, was a Lebanese Christian Maronite.

title: Energy Stocks Are Black Eye on the S&P 500, Again
summary: The sector dropped 11% this month, its worst January on record. The S&P 500 energy sector entered a bear market Friday, registering its worst January on record as oil prices dropped on concerns about global growth.

title: Bloomberg Put $200 Million Into Campaign in First Five Weeks
summary: More than $140 million went toward TV and digital advertising; $679,000 was spent on short-term, corporate housing for staff. Michael Bloomberg put about $200 million of his own money into his presidential campaign in its first five weeks, roughly the same amount as the rest of the Democratic field had spent in the third quarter.

title: SEC Proposes Amending Corporate Disclosure Rules
summary: Regulator is looking to give executives more flexibility in what they share with investors. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is proposing changes to rules governing how companies disclose financial information-the latest move by the regulator to give executives more flexibility in what they share with investors.

title: Aluminum-Foil Maker Goes Public, Banking on Home Cooking
summary: Company says frugal millennials will drive sales of its products; shares rise nearly 10% in debut. The 100-year-old maker of Reynolds Wrap went public on Friday, banking that budget-conscious, home-cooking millennials will drive sales of products from aluminum foil to sandwich bags.

title: Trump Administration Imposes New Travel Restrictions on Six Countries
summary: Citizens from Nigeria, Eritrea, Myanmar and Kyrgyzstan won't be allowed to apply for visas to immigrate to U.S. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is banning immigration from Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, and three other countries in an expansion of its policy blocking travel from seven other nations.

title: Exxon's Growth Gambit Failing to Yield Higher Profits
summary: Energy giant is ramping up spending to pump more, but earnings are declining amid lower oil and gas prices. Exxon Mobil Corp. is still struggling to bolster its bottom line, nearly two years into a plan to substantially boost oil and gas production by spending more than rivals.

title: Crop Prices Dip Despite Trade Deals
summary: Farmers say lower prices for corn and soybeans complicate planting plans. Crop prices have dropped since the signing of trade deals meant to buoy the farm economy, clouding the outlook for farmers working to secure financing for this spring's planting season.

title: Market Closure, Coronavirus Disrupt Pricing on China ETFs
summary: While China's stock markets have been closed, billions of dollars in exchange-traded funds made up of Chinese A-shares have been trading, and they have fallen sharply. Exchange-traded funds pegged to mainland Chinese stocks face one of their biggest pricing dislocations in years, as the country's stock market braces for the financial fallout of the worsening coronavirus outbreak.

title: Weinstein Accuser Describes Alleged Rape
summary: The former aspiring actress continued a relationship with the Hollywood producer for years despite multiple alleged sexual assaults. A former aspiring actress who had a long-term relationship with Harvey Weinstein accused him of violently raping her in a New York City hotel, giving searing testimony about a crucial incident underpinning the charges against the Hollywood producer.

title: Biotech Stocks Swing on Coronavirus Vaccine Hopes
summary: Shares that surged last week on hopes for a coronavirus vaccine have since shed their gains. Biotechnology stocks that surged last week on hopes for a coronavirus vaccine have since shed their gains, highlighting the risks investors take when they invest in the volatile sector.

title: GOP Senators Appear Likely to Reject Witnesses in Impeachment Trial
summary: Sen. Lisa Murkowski says she will oppose new witnesses; only two GOP senators have said they will support such a move. WASHINGTON-The Senate appeared likely to reject new witnesses or documents in President Trump's impeachment trial after Democrats fell short in their effort to pick up key Republican votes, clearing the way for a rapid acquittal on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

title: U.S. Removes Cosco Shipping Units From Blacklist
summary: Restriction tied to Iranian trade was applied to Cosco Group businesses in September. The U.S. Treasury Department on Friday removed sanctions on two tanker operators within China's Cosco Group that were blacklisted last year for allegedly transporting Iranian oil in violation of U.S. prohibitions.

title: Nike Vaporfly Shoes Won't Be Banned From Olympics
summary: After helping smash marathon records, Nike's controversial sneaker can still be used by athletes in Tokyo Games. The current version of Nike Inc.'s controversial high-tech Vaporfly sneakers won't be banned in elite competition, a decision that will fuel further debate about the shoe's perceived competitive advantage ahead of this summer's Tokyo Olympics.

title: New Democratic Debate Rules Could Put Bloomberg on Stage
summary: DNC eliminates previous fundraising criterion and now gives candidates three ways to qualify. DES MOINES, Iowa-The Democratic National Committee announced new rules for the Feb. 19 debate in Nevada that eliminates a previous fundraising criterion, giving former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg a chance to qualify.

title: Boeing Lines Up Funding Options
summary: Amid MAX crisis, company arranges $12 billion bank loan. Boeing Co. has lined up at least $12 billion in bank loans and may tap the commercial paper market to counter the cash drain from the 737 MAX crisis.

title: Insurance Tycoon Greg Lindberg's Bribery Case Heads to Court
summary: Bids by Lindberg and two fellow defendants to have charges dismissed fail. Insurance mogul Greg Lindberg's criminal trial on federal bribery charges is set to start Feb. 18, after a federal judge denied motions by Mr. Lindberg and two fellow defendants to dismiss charges against them.

title: IBM Splits the Difference
summary: Leadership shake-up mixes old and new at storied tech giant. How does one shake up the leadership of a century-old company that prides itself on stability in the top ranks? The answer from IBM's board: Very carefully.

title: IKEA's Meatball Supply Chain Goes Digital
summary: The furniture retailer is bringing new supply-chain discipline to its multibillion-dollar food service business. IKEA wants to bring the supply-chain precision behind its flat-pack furniture business to the way it manages meatballs and lingonberry jam.

title: Moderates Fear Suburban Backlash to a Sanders Nomination
summary: Some officials see nightmare scenario that includes falling short in Rust Belt. MODERATE DEMOCRATS SEARCH for alternative to Sen. Bernie Sanders as he rises in the polls. Some party officials and independent expenditure groups focused on down-ballot races worry he could arrest the Democratic suburban expansion. The nightmare scenario involves falling short in the bet that Sanders's populist credentials can win back the Rust Belt, while also losing some of the front-line suburban districts won by Democrats in 2018. Sanders's rivals have been playing up their ability to win there: "I bring the receipts of bringing in people in the suburbs," Sen. Amy Klobuchar said this week, while former Vice President Joe Biden noted his success campaigning for suburban candidates in the 2018 midterms.

title: Amish and Mennonite Investors Were Targeted in Dairy Fraud, Prosecutors Say
summary: Dairy owner Philip Riehl bilked Pennsylvania religious communities in $60 million Ponzi scheme, federal prosecutors allege. Federal prosecutors have charged the owner of a bankrupt dairy business in Pennsylvania with defrauding some $60 million from members of the Amish and Mennonite religious communities.

title: Ex-HBO Boss and Apple Producer Plepler Looks to Hire Vice News Chief
summary: Josh Tyrangiel, former executive producer of Emmy-winning 'Vice News Tonight,' is in talks to join Eden Productions. Former HBO boss Richard Plepler is seeking to recruit Vice Media veteran Josh Tyrangiel to his new production company, Eden Productions, people familiar with the situation said, a move that would add an executive with news experience as his outfit prepares to make shows for Apple Inc .

title: Goodell Unlikely to Face Impeachment over Tailgating Limits
summary: Imagine what the free men and women of Kansas City could achieve in a Super Bowl parking lot.. For security reasons, the NFL will be applying its usual restrictions on pre-game festivities at Sunday's Super Bowl game in Miami. The policy will be especially difficult to bear for fans of the American Football Conference champion Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Thoughts on Witnesses and the Impeachment
summary: We should hear from all appropriate witnesses-in the House of Representatives.. I totally agree with William A. Galston's "Let's Hear From John Bolton" (Politics & Ideas, Jan. 29). We should hear from all appropriate witnesses-in the House of Representatives.

title: Just Say No to Warren's Student-Debt Plan
summary: Why would anyone in their right mind be making payments on their student loans at this point?. Regarding your editorial "Elizabeth Warren Meets an Irate Dad" (Jan. 25): It isn't just parents who saved who are irate about the inherent unfairness of Sen. Warren's student-debt forgiveness proposal-some millennials are as well. My father is a blue-collar worker in Arkansas, where I grew up. While he taught me the value of hard work and personal responsibility, something for which I will always be grateful, with four younger siblings, a college fund was never in the picture. I went to a public university for an undergraduate degree on a scholarship and an expensive private university in the Northeast for grad school. Instead of staying in the Northeast or moving to the Bay Area like many I knew, I left my friends and moved to Dallas for the job market and because I knew I would be able to pay off my debt more quickly. I have been aggressive about repayment and am happy to say I will be finished this year.

title: Making that Old Fur Fly Into Something More Useful
summary: The best idea was four teddy bears.. When my mother-in-law, a woman more svelte than I, offered her various fur coats to me several years ago, I took them ("When No One Wants Grandma's Mink Coat," Life & Arts, Jan. 28). We sat down together and discussed how each could best be reimagined. Yes, a vest, a collar, a small cape, but the best idea was four teddy bears.

title: We Wish Carter's 'Persian Gulf Success' on Adversaries
summary: Until President Carter there was no need for a Carter Doctrine.. Taylor Dinerman leaves out one indispensable fact when proclaiming "Jimmy Carter's Persian Gulf Success" (op-ed, Jan. 23): Until President Carter there was no need for a Carter Doctrine. The Persian Gulf was secured by our Persian allies, led by the shah of Iran, whom President Carter pressured to abdicate, enabling the fanatical Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeni to assume power and create the Islamic Republic. The predictable result of President Carter's disastrous meddling is what necessitated the continuous deployment of American troops to the Gulf for the past 40 years. I wish all our enemies such "success."

title: Twitter Removes GOP-Run Account That Impersonated Democrat
summary: Social-media profile operated by New Hampshire Republican Party mimicked gubernatorial candidate. Twitter Inc. on Thursday took down an account run by the New Hampshire Republican Party that mimicked a Democratic opponent, highlighting the continuing challenge social-media companies face in determining what is political disinformation and should be taken down.

title: In Iowa, Would-Be Presidents Still Build Trust One Voter at a Time
summary: The first-in-the-nation caucuses reward retail politics, not huge bank accounts. It's a quadrennial rite of winter. On Monday, as night falls across the snow-streaked landscape of Iowa, in populous cities with prosaic names like Ames and Davenport and sparse counties with evocative names like Chickasaw and Pocahontas, little knots of highly motivated citizens will bundle up and head for drafty schools and dimly lit public libraries to cast the first votes in the U.S. presidential election.

title: Reviving Syria's Economy Is an Uphill Battle for Assad After Years of War
summary: Plunging currency sends prices of food, medicine and transportation soaring, fueling rare demonstrations against the regime. Syrian President Bashar al-Assadhas all but won a devastating nine-year war, but he faces a challenge to revive an economy devastated by war, shunned by foreign investors and strangled by Western sanctions.

title: KKR Swings to Profit, Aims for Russell Indexes Inclusion
summary: Private-equity firm's distributable earnings beat expectations in latest quarter; shares rise. Private-equity firm KKR & Co. swung to a fourth-quarter profit and said it is working toward being included in the Russell stock indexes, sending its shares higher.

title: U.S. Consumer Spending, Wage Gains Eased in Late 2019
summary: Household spending rose 0.3% in December from the month prior, while personal income advanced 0.2%. WASHINGTON-Consumer spending and wage gains eased at the end of last year, signs the U.S. economy is returning to a more moderate pace of growth.

title: The Super Bowl Is Still TV's Ballgame, With Streaming Far Behind
summary: Fox's streaming-only ads for the Super Bowl were priced between $300,000 and $400,000 for 30 seconds of ad time. The internet may be steadily transforming the TV business, but there is one day a year when viewers and advertisers still act like almost nothing has changed: Super Bowl Sunday.

title: Honeywell Says Outlook Clouded by MAX Grounding, Coronavirus
summary: Industrial conglomerate says production halt of Boeing plane would hurt its aerospace business after previously projecting minimal impact. Honeywell International Inc.'s fourth-quarter profit dropped 9% on lower sales after spinning off two divisions last year.

title: Mexican President Polishes Fiscal Bona Fides
summary: Government spending was flat in 2019; data show bigger-than-expected surplus before debt payments. MEXICO CITY-Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador reaffirmed his credentials as a fiscal conservative in his first year in office, posting flat government spending and generating a bigger-than-expected surplus before debt payments.

title: Trump Strengthens Efforts Against Human Trafficking
summary: President orders new position and website for victims, mandates departmental coordination. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Friday signed an executive order aimed at combating human trafficking and online exploitation, the White House said.

title: The Chinese Art Deco Look: Too Ornate for a Tiny Apartment?
summary: In a 740-square-foot Manhattan flat, a doctor realizes his childhood dream of living in a 1930s film set. The secret: strategic interior design. YOU MIGHT NOT expect a future doctor to be dazzled by unhealthy habits. But as a child, Eli Greenberg lustfully watched stars spark cigarettes and imbibe spirits in 1930s-era films like "The Thin Man." "Everyone was so sophisticated in this elegant, modern world where there was a stylish accoutrement for every vice," said Dr. Greenberg, a psychiatrist. The Art Deco sets-with their opulent mix of woods and metals and stylized geometrics-left a resonating impression. "I wanted to live in a space like that," he recalled.

title: Laszlo Bock Thinks Machine Learning Can Make Work Better
summary: A Google veteran's new firm uses artificial intelligence to send employees 'nudges' to prod them toward changes likely to produce a happier workforce. Tech founder Laszlo Bock likes to cite Aristotle on the two kinds of happiness. The ancient Greek philosopher spoke not only of hedonic happiness, Mr. Bock says, which has to do with pleasure and having a good time, but also of eudaemonic happiness, which is about feeling purpose and fulfillment. In Aristotelian ethics, this second kind of happiness is the highest human good. Mr. Bock expounds: "It turns out that if you drive meaning and purpose at work, people feel more eudaemonic happiness-and when they feel more eudaemonic happiness, they perform better and stick around longer."

title: What Past Crises Tell Us About the Coronavirus
summary: Overreaction, overconfidence and confusion have damaged previous public health efforts. The fast-spreading outbreak of a new coronavirus in Wuhan, China, has spurred a cascade of public health responses, which some critics have faulted for sluggishness, others for overreach. Millions of Chinese have been quarantined, foreigners (including more than 200 Americans) have been evacuated from the region and flights to the country have been curtailed.

title: Ross: Coronavirus Outbreak Could Help Bring Jobs Back to U.S.
summary: 'It does give businesses another thing to consider when they do a review of their supply chains,' the U.S. Commerce secretary said. WASHINGTON-U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said the coronavirus outbreak in China could help bring jobs to America, a remark that was quickly criticized as insensitive to China's plight.

title: If Mr. Peanut Has to Go, Why Does the Gecko Get to Live?
summary: It is character assassination: Planters is offing a beloved mascot on Super Bowl Sunday, but surely there are others more deserving. The announcement that the Planters brand would kill off its mega-iconic Mr. Peanut during the Super Bowl initially prompted laughter in many quarters, with "Saturday Night Live" showing an image of the mascot after he had been "cream-ated." Now, despite calls to pull the ad from the Super Bowl lineup out of respect for Kobe Bryant-because Mr. Peanut is depicted dying in a fiery accident-Planters insisted during the week that Mr. Peanut's demise and funeral will go on as scheduled.

title: Fed Intervenes With $45.55 Billion Weekend Repo, But Overall Liquidity Ticks Down
summary: Fed money-market interventions are aimed at keeping the federal-funds rate within the central bank's 1.5%-to-1.75% target range. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York executed a $45.55 billion weekend liquidity operation Friday, which resulted in led overall temporary central bank liquidity to tick lower.

title: Poised Between Two Worlds
summary: This representation of Avalokiteshvara, known as Gwaneum in Korea, is a way station between tension and repose, between petitioners and gods.

title: 'The Bomb' Review: Down the Nuclear Rabbit Hole
summary: Until 1989, no president had ever been privy to the military's list of specific targets in the Soviet Union.. In the summer of 1945, as a mushroom cloud rose high above the Japanese city of Hiroshima, the very history of war and diplomacy, and the world of Great Power relations, changed irrevocably. Science had created a weapon of such indiscriminate destructiveness that it ought, now that its ferocity was clear, never to be used again. This became even more obvious to contemporary observers when the more powerful hydrogen bombs appeared on the scene only a few years later, and when the Soviet Union also quickly acquired similar weaponry.

title: 'Physical Intelligence' Review: Mind-Body Know-How
summary: Crawling, walking, grabbing, poking, climbing: Our physical capabilities hinge on our bodies anticipating what we're going to do before we do it. (That's why you can't tickle yourself.). A favorite trick of child psychologists is to put a baby on a table with a glass section in the middle. Will the baby scuttle across the transparent area, or does he instinctively know that it's not a good idea to crawl over cliff edges? Curiously, despite repeated experiments, psychologists have not been able to agree on an answer. Babies are so active that it's hard to tell whether those that do end up on the glass are innately foolhardy or have accidentally learned that it is safe.

title: 'A House in the Mountains' Review: Four Against Fascism
summary: There were more women partisans in the Italian resistance than in any similar movement in occupied Europe. They acted as lookouts, arranged escape routes, even kidnapped German officers.. In the last days of April 1945, recriminations following the liberation of the north of Italy brought widespread killings. After the Germans retreated, partisan leaders called for a "rapid and radical cleansing" to avenge their dead. "The knife must be plunged into the wound," urged one, "and everything rotten cut out."

title: 'The Fire and the Darkness' Review: Der Feuersturm
summary: Dresden was known as 'Florence on the Elbe,' but its beauty and history offered no protection during the war's endgame.. 'The Fire and the Darkness," Sinclair McKay's new account of the destruction from the air of Dresden during the night of Feb. 13-14, 1945, is determined to do justice to the complex nature of this extraordinarily seductive German city-and most especially to the artistic and architectural glories that led to its being dubbed "Florence on the Elbe."

title: Five Best: Max Hastings on Diaries of World War II
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'Operation Chastise: The RAF's Most Brilliant Attack of World War II.'. Edited by James Leutze (1972)

title: Fiction: David, Bathsheba and Sir Thomas Wyatt
summary: A brilliant novel of adultery, penitence and psalmistry with a curious double focus-the courts of King David and Henry VIII.. Perhaps some bookish friend has pressed on you a copy of Elizabeth Cook's "Achilles," the small, luminous reimagining of Homer's "Iliad" that has been borne aloft by word of mouth since it was published in 2001. If so, then you won't be surprised by the intelligence, originality and poetic grace of Ms. Cook's latest novel, "Lux" (Scribe, 408 pages, $17), which again reworks a text from antiquity-this time the biblical story of King David and Bathsheba.

title: Mysteries: Selflessly Blowing His Cover
summary: In Harry Dolan's latest, a man performs a heroic deed that makes him nationally famous-and gets the attention of dangerous enemies he fled from years before.. Houston resident Sean Tennant, the title character in Harry Dolan's slick and twisty "The Good Killer" (Mysterious Press, 341 pages, $26), grew up in Detroit as Sean Garrety. His life partner, Molly Winter, was once known as Molly Bowen. The two have fled their old home and established new identities. They've set rules for themselves to ensure their mutual safety: "They've left the people they used to know behind. They don't see them or talk to them, ever." And they "stay clear of where they used to live. The state of Michigan is off-limits."

title: 'The Professor and the Parson' Review: Father of Lies
summary: Rev. Robert Peters was a compulsive fraud, forger, debt-dodger and womanizer with a bottomless hunger for status, both professorial and sacerdotal.. 'Peters the parson hoaxes Oxford": So ran a front-page headline in a British tabloid in February 1959. According to the story beneath, a Rev. Robert Peters had duped Magdalen College "into giving him a big social wedding-and almost into giving him a degree." Admitted to a postgraduate program, Peters had married a fellow Oxford student and persuaded Magdalen to hold a service of blessing in its chapel. Then the college learned that he had faked his credentials and had led, under a different name, a life of infamy that included three previous marriages (one bigamous), two terms in jail and a rare defrocking by the Church of England.

title: Children's Books: All Woke-and All Winners
summary: On hue, heritage and the American Library Association's Youth Media Awards for 2020.. Members of the general public may be unaware of the degree to which identity politics are pervading the world of children's literature. Books are increasingly assessed as much for the racial and ethnic backgrounds of those creating the art as for the excellence of the art itself. A social-media commentator caught the zeitgeist this week with unintentional comic brilliance. During the American Library Association's initial announcements of its biggest accolades on Monday, this plaintive tweet went out: "Love the ALA awards and seeing so many worthy books recognized. But if I were a female/non-binary illustrator, I imagine I'd feel a little discouraged right now."

title: 'The Lost Girls' Review: High Minds and Slender Means
summary: An empathetic group biography of four bright, beautiful, literary women in wartime London.. When I was 17 I chanced upon a book belonging to my father called "The Unquiet Grave." It was a slim volume published in 1944 under the pseudonym Palinurus, the doomed pilot of Aeneas's ship. The author was Cyril ConnolIy, editor of Horizon, a celebrated English literary monthly that came out between 1939 and 1950. His maxims and observations upon life, love, art and religion, accompanied by a large dose of personal angst, heartily appealed to my sensibility. As far as I was concerned, Cyril Connolly was a god.

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended January 25
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Squatters Cut Down the Rainforest. Brazil Wants to Give Them the Land.
summary: Resume Subscription. POMBAL, Brazil-For the past 15 years, Carlos Pacheco has raised cattle in what was once virgin forest. When pastures went bad, he would simply cut deeper into the Amazon, one of millions of farmers who have helped strip away about a fifth of the world's greatest rainforest.

title: Stressed Out at the Office? Therapy Can Come to You
summary: A growing number of employers, from Dell to Delta, are bringing in therapists for counseling on-site. The therapist will see you now-in your office.

title: The Stock Got Crushed. Then the ETFs Had to Sell.
summary: The intense trading in a beaten-down company's shares shows how important it is for index-fund investors to understand what they own.

title: The American Dream Is Alive and Well
summary: Don't listen to the populist naysayers: The U.S. economy continues to deliver jobs, higher wages and upward mobility for those who need it most.. What do President Trump and Bernie Sanders have in common? Or Fox News host Tucker Carlson, Nobel Prize-winning Clinton administration economist Joseph Stiglitz and billionaire investor Ray Dalio? Among many other prominent elected officials, commentators, public intellectuals and business leaders, they have all voiced concern about the death of the American Dream.

title: The iPhone Isn't Made in China-It's Made Everywhere
summary: The global supply chains behind Apple's smartphone show why trade deficits are so pointless as a measure of economic strength. At the Jan. 15 White House signing ceremony for an initial trade deal with China, President Trump's top trade negotiator, Robert Lighthizer, noted that his boss "has, for years, complained about our enormous trade deficit with China." Indeed, Mr. Trump and others have long considered that gap a reflection of American economic weakness. The premise seems to be that a $420 billion trade deficit with China is akin to Washington just forking over $420 billion to Beijing each year. In 2012, Mr. Trump tweeted that "every year... China is making almost $300 billion off the United States." This is the equivalent of saying that your local gas station "made $20 off you" when you put $20 worth of gas in your car.

title: Trump, Pence Show Off Contrasting Styles in Iowa Visits
summary: GOP incumbents' re-election campaign seeks to leverage mass rallies and traditional politicking. DES MOINES, Iowa-In Iowa just days before the state's kickoff caucuses, President Trump pumped up a megarally while Vice President Mike Pence ordered a deluxe burger.

title: Canadian Economy Expanded Slightly in November
summary: Biggest contributor to the monthly gain was the utilities sector, which rose 2.1%. OTTAWA-The Canadian economy expanded slightly in November on a strong advance in the utilities sector, beating market expectations and mostly offsetting the previous month's decline.

title: Tech Sector Fears Supply Delays as Effects of Virus Ripple Through China
summary: Impact beyond Wuhan, a transportation hub and center for tech and auto manufacturing, will be clear in coming weeks, analysts said. HONG KONG-The world's biggest tech companies are facing disruptions to their supply chains from prolonged factory closures and labor shortages in China, as the deadly coronavirus outbreak threatens the nation's vast manufacturing network.

summary: OECD members struggle to find consensus on taxing big tech and other multinationals. A U.S. proposal on how to tax U.S. tech giants met broad opposition just days after a trade battle over the issue was averted, reflecting continued tensions between Washington and Europe on the divisive issue.

title: Seeing Artists Face to Face
summary: In Amsterdam, a new exhibition explores van Gogh's place in the history of self-portraits.. Visual artists have been depicting themselves since antiquity, but the self-portrait took on a new urgency in the 19th century. The evolution of the modern art market in Paris, which placed high value on an artist's fame, coincided with the Romantic movement's demand that artists be viewed as creative geniuses.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Refocus Ire on City's Handling of Coronavirus Crisis
summary: Pro-establishment groups join antigovernment activists to criticize management of the health emergency. title: Clock Begins Ticking on Key Brexit Goals
summary: Five important issues that the U.K. and EU are aiming to resolve within 11 months. Both the U.K. and the European Union say they are seeking a broad free-trade accord covering goods and services, but there are doubts whether such a deal can be reached in such a short time. Without a deal or extra time to reach agreement, the U.K. faces an abrupt and messy rupture with its neighbors.

title: Where Democratic Candidates Might Look for Support in Iowa Caucuses
summary: Presidential contenders will have to stitch together support from various coalitions of voters. The Iowa Democratic Party is preparing for potentially record turnout in the Feb. 3 caucuses, but those participating will still represent only a fraction of the state's voters. More than a third of registered voters are independents, with the rest roughly evenly split between Democrats and Republicans. Even a record-setting turnout would likely amount to less than half of registered Democrats. (Republicans and independents may also participate in the Democratic caucuses, but they will have to change their party affiliation to do so.)

title: The 2019 Growth Slowdown
summary: GDP growth fell to a 2% annual trend. Trade friction is the culprit.. President Trump promised to lift the economy above the 2% growth trend of the Obama years, and for a while tax reform and deregulation did the trick. But his trade and tariff forays undermined business investment and global manufacturing, and the economy is now back down to a 2% growth plateau. That's nowhere near a recession, but it's disappointing as a lost opportunity.

title: Forest Bathing Is Fashion's Way to Find Calm
summary: How celebrity and influencer evangelists for the Japanese art of tree-hugging are powering it to new heights. When shoe and accessory designer Aurora James was nine years old, she walked deep into a forest with her mother before they broke into separate areas to meditate. It was her first time forest bathing. Over the years, communing with nature "made all of my teenage problems seem much more temporary and fleeting," James, 35, writes over email. "I have only just recently heard of forest bathing, but I've been doing it my entire life."
